awd_titl_txt: NSF/MCB-BSF: Developing a metavirome assembler for uncovering the global virome
awd_abstract_narration:
While viruses are the most diverse biological entities on Earth, challenges in their genome sequencing have prevented surveys of Earth's virome. The key obstacle on the way towards exploration of viral diversity is the absence of computational methods of assembling virus genomes from the short overlapping sequences of DNA obtained when sequencing DNA from a wide range of environments.  This project will develop such methods to enable a more complete cataloging of virus genomes and provide a critical new resource for microbiology.  In addition, it will result in a new online learning classes at UCSD and Tel Aviv University as well as an online capstone project aimed at analyzing viral genomes. This activity will extend the online Coursera Specializations 'Bioinformatics' and the Massive Online Open Course (MOOC) "Gut Check: Exploring Your Microbiome" by including a new metagenomics component. This educational effort will reach thousands of students from all over the world since these MOOCs have large enrollments.

This project will result in new genome assemblers specifically aimed at reconstructing the viral component of metagenomes. It will enable the development of a new metavirome assembler aimed at discovery of complete viral genomes across a wide range of environments. This research will result in reassembling all publicly available metagenomics datasets to compile the global catalog of complete viral genomes, which will enable the exploration of viral diversity.

This collaborative US/Israel project is supported by the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Biological Sciences Directorate and the Computational Biology activity in the Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering Directorate at the US National Science Foundation and by the Israeli Binational Science Foundation.

por.por_cntn:
The key goal of this project is the development of a specialized viral assembler and discovery of novel viruses.

We have developed a short-read metaviralSPAdes assembler (Antipov et al., Bioinformatics 2020) and entered into a collaboration with the National Center for Biotechnology Information at NIH aimed at discovery of novel viral genomes from all publicly available short-read metagenomics datasets (Yutin et al., Nature Communications 2021). We also released metaFlye long-read metagenomic assembler (Kolmogorov et al., Nature Methods 2020) that includes a special module for assembling viral genomes. In collaboration with Israeli viral expert Itzik Mizrahi and USDA scientists, we demonstrated that novel HiFi reads, in combination with metaFlye, opened the era of “complete metagenomics”, enabling sequencing many novel viral genomes In this paper, we also described a novel approach for connecting the newly reconstructed viral genomes with their microbial hosts. This paper (Bickhart, Kolmogorov, et al. “Generation of lineage-resolved complete metagenome-assembled genomes in complex microbial communities” has been accepted for publication in Nature Biotechnology.

We further improved viral assembly in metaFlye and developed a specialized viralFlye long-read viral assembler (paper accepted in Genome Biology). In this paper, we described a novel CRISPR-based technique for connecting the newly reconstructed viral genomes with their microbial hosts. Although identification of known CRISPR spacers in metagenome-assembled viruses (MAVs) is a widely used approach for predicting potential known hosts for novel viruses from metagenome assemblies, this sample-independent approach does not analyze bacteria present in the sample and is not applicable to still unknown CRISPR spacers. In the viralFlye paper, we demonstrate that the identification of novel CRISPR arrays in bacterial genomes from a newly assembled metagenomic sample (sample-dependent approach) provides information for predicting potential novel hosts for novel viruses and results in a large number of identified virus-host associations.

Using metaviralSPAdes, metaFlye, and viralFlye we discovered and analyzed many novel viruses in diverse datasets, for example new subfamilies of recently discovered crAssphages can now be discovered with a push-of-a-button (as opposed to the time- consuming manual analysis as in Yutin et al., Nature Microbiology 2018)) using our assemblers.

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2021
Modified by: Pavel A Pevzner
